Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: REU Site on Smart Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This site is co-funded by the Department of Defense in partnership with the NSF REU program.

This funding renews a CISE Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) Site at Auburn University focused on smart unmanned aerial vehicles (smart UAVs). The students design algorithms and techniques to safely, securely, and efficiently fly in a limited field a fleet of autonomous UAVs. A nationwide recruitment process is used to select cohorts of undergraduate students to participate in an eight-week summer research program at the host institution. Particular emphasis is placed on recruitment of students from under-represented populations. The project includes mentoring by the experienced computer science faculty members, technical seminars and workshops, student presentations, and field trips and other professional development opportunities.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in strong research basis and the expertise of the faculty. The projects are in current research areas that are of interest to the community at large and that have clear practical applications. The students participate in a full range of research activities from preparing research literature reviews to production and dissemination of research results.

The broader impacts of the project include providing a quality research experience to undergraduate students, particularly students from underrepresented groups. The participating faculty members are committed to including under-represented minority students in their research. Thus this project has the potential to produce new computer science graduate students and faculty members and to advance discovery and understanding while promoting learning.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The REU Site on Smart Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) was originally funded to offer a research experience to 27 undergraduates in the field of unmanned flight. Ultimately, this REU site offered such an experience to 30 undergraduates during Summers 2012, 2013, and 2014. In addition, for this last year from May 1, 2015 to April 30, 2016, this REU site hosted three Auburn students throughout the academic year. These three undergraduates worked on two problems:

1) Battery efficiency study for the Bixler UAV.

2) Fail safe system for UAVs.

For the first problem, an undergraduate student studied the time a battery lasts depending on the flight conditions with the objective to find ways to use the battery for longer missions. Currently, our experiments are limited to 10 mn flights. This limitation greatly hampers our progress and does not allow us to properly evaluate the collision avoidance algorithms that this REU site implemented.

For the second problem, two undergraduate students designed a system to monitor an UAV and diagnose failure conditions to deploy a parachute system. The objective is to make crashes safer. Given the recent FAA regulations, we want to insure that all our flight tests are safe for our students and the general public.
